description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 EAC-sekretariatet has ansökt om stöd för ett integrerat regionalt hälsoprogram under 2016-2020.
Programmets syfte är att, på policynivå, hantera svagheter inom medlemländernas hälsosystem. Om EACs medlemsländer gemensamt och effektivt harmoniserar standarder för SRHR-, mödra-, barn-och HIV/AIDS-hälsotjänster kommer detta att stärka det regional samarbetet inom hälsa. Vidare syftar interventionen till att stärka relevant forskning, innovationer, kunskapsspridning, ledarskap, styrning och ansvarsutkrävande inom regionen. EAC förväntar sig att det långsiktiga resultatet av ett fördjupat samarbete inom ovan nämnda områden kommer att vara att snabbare nå målen om att eliminera den mödra- och barnadödlighet som går att förhindra och att på sikt stoppa AIDS-epidemin.
Projektet har en budget på 45 miljoner kronor över 4,25 år och Sida är den enda givaren. Projektet är en del av EAC-sekretariatets mer övergripande hälsostrategi som omfattar även andra givare. Huvuddelen av projektets kostnader omfattas av löner för anställda vid EAC-sekretariatet samt kostnader för de processer som framtagande av EAC-gemensamma policydokument innebär (möteskostnader, resor m.m).

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The EAC secretariat has applied for support to the EAC-Sida integrated health program 2016-2020.
The purpose of the program is to, at a policy level, address weaknesses of member states' health systems. If the member states collectively and effectively harmonize standards for SRHR- maternal-, child and HIV/AIDS health services this will in turn strengthen regional cooperation in health. Furthermore, the program seeks to strengthen relevant research, innovation, knowledge management, leadership, governance and accountability within the region. The EAC expects that the long-term outcome of a deeper collaboration in the abovementioned areas will be that the goals of eliminating preventable maternal- and child mortality and eventually ending the AIDS-epidemic can be reached faster.
The project has a budget of 45 million SEK over 4.25 years and Sida is the sole donor. The project part of the EAC-secretariats more overarching health strategy which includes also other donors. The majority of costs are represented by salaries of project staff at the EAC-secretariat and costs related to development of EAC policies (e.g. workshops, travels, consultancy fees)

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.
3.3 - By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
3.3 - Senast 2030 utrota epidemierna av aids, tuberkulos, malaria och försummade tropiska sjukdomar samt bekämpa hepatit, vattenburna sjukdomar och andra smittsamma sjukdomar.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8 - Åstadkomma allmän hälso- och sjukvård för alla, som även skyddar mot ekonomisk risk, tillgång till grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård av god kvalitet liksom tillgång till säkra, effektiva och ekonomiskt överkomliga grundläggande läkemedel och vaccin av god kvalitet.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
For the period 1 July 2019 to 30 June 2020, the EAC EIHP contributed to the improvement in the policy environment in the region in the reproductive, maternal and child health and the HIV and AIDS arena primarily through the development of policy instruments.
Results per objective
Objective 1: Harmonize and integrate SRHR/RMNCAH and HIV&AIDS, TB and STIs Service Packages, Standards and Guidelines in the East African Community
- Six country draft country report for the the regional assessment on the status of integration of RMNCAH and HIV&AIDS services in the EAC Partner States complete and awaiting approval (due to Covid no EAC statutory meeting could be held in 2020) - Drafting of the national and regional reports of the EAC Boresha Huduma STIs completed and national teams for the STI study trained - The Regional Minimum standard for RMNCAH and HIV and AIDS integration completed with support from UNFPA and submitted to all 6 Partner States for national validation (facilitated by the EAC Secretariat). Countries mapped out clear steps and a road-map to implement the recommendations. - Data collection for the baseline assessment was concluded, draft report documenting the burden of STIs in the respective partner states completed. - The drafting of the Harmonized EAC regional algorithm for prevention, treatment and diagnosis of STIs was initiated, but not concluded in 2020
Objective 2: Strengthen SRHR/RMNCAH and HIV&AIDS, TB and STIs Research, Innovations and Knowledge Management in the EAC
- The EAC regional Knowledge Management Portal for health https://health.eac.int was maintained and updated. From 14th March to 27th June 2020, the total number of visitors were 48,546 with a weekly average number of visitors 3,034 and a monthly average number of visitors of 12,137. The Web Portal is according to the EAC progressively becoming a one stop centre for EAC regional data and information on SRHR/RMNCAH, HIV/AIDS and STIs.
Objective 3: Strengthen SRHR/RMNCAH and HIV& AIDS, TB and STIs Leadership, Governance and Accountability in the EAC
- During the reporting period, the programme through the Regional Joint Technical meeting of RMNCAH-N and HIV/AIDS, TB & STIs Managers in East Africa, developed and facilitated the adoption of a Ministerial Commitment on the 25th Anniversary of the ICPD. The commitment was adopted during the 19th Sectoral Council of Ministers of Health held in October, and was read during the ICPD 25, conference in Nairobi, by the Chair of the Sectoral Council on Health. - The programme reinvigorated the EAC Sexual Reproductive Health and Rights bill. Working in collaboration with civil society and UNFPA, the programme engaged the East African Legislative Assembly (EALA) so that the Bill can be reintroduced in the regional house.
- With the support of UNFPA, a consultant began to review and update the draft bill, informed by a desk review whose aim to identify the key issues around SRHR in the region and update the Bill accordingly.
- Several forums were convened virtually to review and build consensus on the various articles. Thereafter, the draft EAC Sexual and Reproductive Health Bill 2020 was presented to the General Purpose Committee (GPC) of the East African Legislative Assembly (EALA) for further discussion and input. The GPC flagged a number issues that are likely to raise controversy once tabled in the House and these are currently being addressed to ensure that members are comfortable with the Bill.
Objective 4: Strengthen the EAC Regional and National Health Systems towards universal health coverage of SRHR/RMNCAH and HIV &AIDS, TB and STIs services
- The 2nd Joint Ministerial, Development Partners and Investors Round-table on investment in Health to mobilize resources for investment in health was convened in October 2019, in Nairobi Kenya. - Helped also convene 19th Sectoral Council of Ministers responsible for Health on 1st November, 2019
- The programme disseminated the Universal Health and HIV Coverage Resource Mobilization Strategy 2018-2023 to stakeholders in the region, through a virtual meeting organised in collaboration with UNAIDS. The strategy was developed to support implementation of the EAC Framework of Action on Sustainable Financing for health and HIV & AIDS (EFOA) and innovative financing mechanisms, in line with the EAC Health Sector Investment Priorities Framework (2018-2028)
-A resource tracking tool with indicators to track health financing in the region, monitor resources mobilized to support the implementation of the EAC Health Sector Investment Priority Framework (2018-2028) and the progress made by Partner States in achieving the UHHC targets, was developed. This tool also aims to provide key information that will help to step up advocacy for increasing domestic resources for health to achieve the UHC targets.
Objective 5: Strengthen the capacity of EAC Secretariat and Partner States to coordinate and implement the project and related global and Africa regional Initiatives
- M&E and Linkages & partnerships officers were finally recruited
- The programme convened one meeting of the JTWG / RMNCAH and HIV and AIDS managers in October 2020, and several virtual expert (4) meetings with the experts from the Partner States.
- Two meetings of the Expert Working Group on Sustainable Financing were held to discuss the resource tracking tool and the harmonized indicator framework for each Partner State. Further, the programme convened a virtual meeting and disseminated the regional resource mobilization strategy, and each country reviewed the national priority action plans for UHHC financing
- In support of the organisations efforts to address the COVID-19 pandemic, the EIHP team is a member of the EAC Regional Coordination Committee that oversees the response in the region. The team has participated in resource mobilisation efforts with the African Development Bank (AfDB), Africa CDC, American CDC Corona, Skoll Foundation, among others to respond to the pandemic. In addition, the programme has participated in activities aimed at raising awareness and community mobilisation to prevent the spread of COVID-19, developed harmonised tools to be used by partner states offering guidelines on prevention, mitigation and testing, and undertook assessment visits to determine the extent to which these guidelines are implemented and determine response to the pandemic. During this exercise, the team advocated for the integration of Sexual reproductive health services to be included as part of the core package of essential services.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
